item.title: Former Ensemble Studios Dev Blames Xbox Head Don Mattrick For ‚ÄòKilling‚Äô Halo MMO
item.content:encoded:
Once upon a time, Halo was set to secure an MMO dubbed ‚ÄòTitan‚Äô, pieced together by Ensemble Studios, a company shut down in January 2009. In a scalding post on social media, Sandy Petersen, who had been with Ensemble since the 1990s, revealed that Don Mattrick, former overseer of the Xbox brand, killed the project to protect his corporate bonus.

This pulling back of the curtain is a fiery look back at the scrapping of a game that, on paper, sounded very interesting.

Titan Was a Prequel MMO in the Halo Universe

In a post on social media, Sandy Petersen, who was once a level designer working on Doom and Quake before joining Ensemble Studios, revealed why Halo‚Äôs ‚ÄòTitan‚Äô MMO never saw the light of day:

In 2008, Ensemble Studios started planning a gigantic MMO set in the Halo universe. We code-named it Titan. It was to take place tens of thousands of years ago, before the Halos were set off & destroyed all sentient life in the Galaxy.

It was all brought to naught when Don Mattrick realized that his stock bonus was based on the income MS had from games in 3 years.

You see, we estimated 3.5 years to finish Titan if we did it right. And that‚Äôs beyond Mattrick‚Äôs drop dead date.

So by firing ALL of Ensemble, he didn‚Äôt have to pay for our expensive studio for 3 years and he didn‚Äôt care about Titan.

Petersen revealed that the would-be Halo MMO would have featured an expansive universe that allowed players to assume control of Forerunners or Covenant characters. The Flood also had a starring spot in the game, but wouldn‚Äôt have been playable, of course.

The quest lines were mapped out, the homeworlds were designed, and Microsoft estimated that the game would have made a whopping $1.1 billion.

Petersen went on to further slam Mattrick, settling on it being part of the executive‚Äôs nature in the industry:P

All he lost was a game studio who never sold less than 3 million copies of everything we made. I don‚Äôt believe he did justice to MicroSoft stockholders but hey ‚Äì Don started as an EA hatchet man so what would you expect?

Petersen and the wider Ensemble Studios team were tasked with bringing to life this ancient Halo setting, and the game was seemingly deep in development when the plug was pulled, and the hand on the cable was Don Mattrick‚Äôs. It was once suggested that Titan would have taken unique concepts, such as time travel, and taken a deep dive into the lore of Halo.

Don Mattrick served as the President of Microsoft‚Äôs Interactive Entertainment arm, overseeing the strategy of Xbox until he departed from the firm in 2013 to instead serve as the CEO of Zynga.

Halo‚Äôs Titan isn‚Äôt to be confused with Blizzard‚Äôs Titan MMO, another canceled game that came to a head after an $80 million investment.

item.title: KT Rolster Shatter Expectations to Reach Worlds 2025 Finals For the First Time
item.content:encoded:
KT Rolster has pulled something monumental out of the bag, handing Gen.G an insane loss at the League of Legends World Championship in Shanghai. This is the first time that KT Rolster has reached such lofty heights, and it came after knocking out one of the favorites to win the entire event.

The devastating loss kicks Gen.G out of the tournament in fourth place, mere weeks after winning the 2025 Mid-Season Invitational, the Esports World Cup, and the LCK 2025 season.

Gen.G Fails to Make Finals Yet Again

Gen.G has now failed to make the finals at LoL Worlds eight years in a row. In 2021, the organization secured a third-place finish, which is the closest the team has been thus far to making the number one spot.

KT Rolster proved to be the obstacle too strong to overcome for Gen.G this time around. The South Korean squad put up one hell of a fight, going the distance in a best-of-five series mere days after devastating CTBC Flying Oyster in a 3 ‚Äì 0 sweep.

The team now has a spot in the Grand Final, poised to fight either T1 or Top Esports. It‚Äôll be one for the history books, especially with T1 sitting on a burner with the squad‚Äôs typical Worlds buff.

In KT Rolster‚Äôs history in the League of Legends space, the organization has won almost nothing to write home about, and in the last three Worlds tournaments the brand has attended, lacklustre finishes have left fans wanting more. Even if KT Rolster doesn‚Äôt win at the November 9 final, it‚Äôll be the biggest single prize the organization has ever claimed ‚Äì $800,000.

item.title: GamerLegion CEO Disputes Claims of 100 Thieves Player Buyout But Confirms Return
item.content:encoded:

In an even more recent post, the CEO of GamerLegion confirmed that no such sales are lined up.

However, the CEO, Nicolas Reber, confirmed that the organization met with 100 Thieves to discuss ‚Äòtheir intention to come back to CS‚Äô. This effectively bolsters the recent suggestions that the LA-based company is breaking back into Counter-Strike.

GamerLegion Isn‚Äôt Selling Players to 100 Thieves

In a post on social media, Nicolas Reber, CEO of GamerLegion, confirmed:

Guess its worth to share.

We had a chat with 100T few weeks ago about their intention to come back to CS, but there is no active discussion about selling any players or cores. We focus on the team we have right now.

Lets get that 3rd place at @pglesports!

The signing of rain hasn‚Äôt been announced yet either, so there‚Äôs still time for that claim to be refuted.

100 Thieves was last seen in Counter-Strike more than five years ago. It‚Äôs a new world these days, but with 100 Thieves preparing to pull out of League of Legends after Worlds, there‚Äôs room for a new roster to rise. The iconic organization fields a current roster in painfully few games, and Counter-Strike is an easy one to step into.

item.title: PGL Reveals Massive Eight-Event CS2 Calendar For 2028
item.content:encoded:
PGL is yet again doubling down on an ongoing commitment to Counter-Strike 2 after unveiling a huge competitive calendar for 2028. Between 2027 and 2028, a whopping 15 Tier 1 tournaments will play out, including a full slate of eight events for 2028 alone. It‚Äôs easily one of the most ambitious schedules in Counter-Strike‚Äôs esports history.

PGL‚Äôs 2027 calendar is looking similarly hefty, with six tournaments being lined up to span January through October.

PGL is Supercharging Counter-Strike 2‚Äôs Calendar

In a press release, the PGL team revealed that 2027 will see six independently produced tournaments and one massive collaboration: the Perfect World Counter-Strike Asia Championships.

Here‚Äôs the schedule revealed thus far for 2027:

IMPORTANT: The following information includes spoilers on today‚Äôs and yesterday‚Äôs editions of Wordle. If you don‚Äôt want the answer given to you, stop scrolling.

How To Play Wordle

Wordle is a simple but addictive word puzzle. Each day, players have to guess a five-letter word answer in no more than six attempts. After each guess:

  • Green letters are correct and in the right position.
  • Yellow letters are correct, but in the wrong position.
  • Gray letters are not in the word at all.

The goal is to guess the word in as few tries as possible. Daily puzzles keep players coming back for more, making it a fun brain exercise and a popular online trend.

Wordle can only be played on the New York Times website. There is currently no app for you to download the official game.

Wordle games are updated daily at 12 am or Midnight in your respective time zone. Information about the next game is often available in the hours before to give players a heads up. The game on November 3 will be Wordle Game #1598.

What Is Wordle?

Wordle is a daily word puzzle created by Josh Wardle. Initially developed as a prototype in 2013, it wasn‚Äôt fully released until 2021. The game challenges players to guess a five-letter word in six tries or fewer, using hints from each attempt to narrow down the answer. Its straightforward concept, accessibility, and the thrill of solving a new puzzle each day helped it surge in popularity by late 2021. The success of Wordle inspired numerous spin-offs and social media challenges, leading to its acquisition by The New York Times in early 2022.

item.title: Casual Mode Added to Battlefield 6 with 32 Bots in Each Match
item.content:encoded:
EA DICE has added a new ‚ÄòCasual Breakthrough‚Äô mode to Battlefield 6 with a new update, accessible via the core multiplayer menu. This new mode is designed to be a more comfortable entry point for new players, allowing them to rank up while fighting mostly bot enemies.

It was stated by EA that teams will consist of eight real players apiece and 16 bot characters per team.

Bots Are Making Life Easier

Die-hard Battlefield fans have argued that this kind of mode shouldn‚Äôt exist outside of Portal, but here it is. Electronic Arts has added Casual Breakthrough to Battlefield 6, introducing a bot-filled mode that allows users to earn career, weapon, and battle pass XP, all while completing challenges and grinding unlocks.

The key thing to note is that any actions against bot characters will reward reduced XP, while taking on human enemies yields the full rewards.

Initially, only Siege of Cairo and Empire State have been added to the map rotation, but it was stressed that EA DICE will be monitoring feedback to ‚Äòdetermine if further adjustments are needed in the future.‚Äô

The only things that don‚Äôt align with the core multiplayer experience are career stat updates, dogtag grabs, and accolades.

Fans were quick to share mixed feedback in the comments section under the post, with many defending the addition. The vibe is, ‚Äòif you don‚Äôt like it, don‚Äôt play it,‚Äô which makes sense.

One concern is that some players will find an inevitable way to turn Casual Breakthrough into an XP farm mode, but let‚Äôs hope that Electronic Arts has its eyes fixed firmly on the data to avoid that happening.
